title: Synthetic Recap
body:
BOSTON (AP) – In a deafening Reunion Arena, the final horn sounded on a masterpiece. It wasn't just a 109-107 victory for the Dallas Mavericks over the Boston Celtics; it was the night Michael Finley authored a performance for the ages, pouring in a career-high and franchise-record 48 points to single-handedly will his team to victory.

From the opening tip, Finley was a man possessed, a relentless force attacking the rim and striking from deep against a vaunted Celtics defense that had no answer. He was the Mavericks' offense, his 48 points representing nearly half of his team's total output in a stunning display of individual brilliance. Every time Boston threatened to build momentum, Finley had a response—a silky jumper, a powerful drive, a clutch three-pointer.

The Celtics, led by a valiant 21-point effort from Rick Fox, fought tooth and nail. They traded blows with the Mavericks throughout a tense fourth quarter, the lead changing hands with each possession. But with the game hanging in the balance, it was always Finley with the ball in his hands, orchestrating the final act of his personal symphony.

When the last second ticked away, the scoreboard told the story of a narrow two-point win. But the stat sheet, and the stunned silence of the Boston bench, told the true tale: one of historic, legendary grandeur. On this night, Michael Finley didn't just beat the Celtics; he transcended the game itself, etching his name into the record books with a performance that will echo through the halls of Reunion Arena forever.
